Description: Body sherd of large Corinthian black-figured pottery alabastron; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of animal frieze to right (only torso of feline with added purple-red on shoulder and stomach, part of hind leg and both forelegs with added purple-red remaining); incised blobs as filling ornament, some with purple-red; below, three bands and two preserved rows of double incised black scale-pattern with added white and purple-red dots.
Curator's comments: Previously identified (by Venit and Möller) as a Late Corinthian oinochoe. The shape and decoration are more consistent with a Middle Corinthian large alabastron. For a similar example, see Payne (1931, 303, fig. 788, pl. 29, fig. 3). C. W. Neeft (personal communication) considers that the alabastron is probably the work of the Scale Painter.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 85, no. A105)
Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 221, no. 4)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GB.148) (Phase 1)
